qas.question: What is the aim of Unicode?

answers.text: transcending the limitations of traditional character encodings

qas.question: Traditional character encodings don't allow what type of computer processing?

answers.text: (computer processing of arbitrary scripts mixed with each other

qas.question: Bilingual computer processing uses what characters?
What is the major limitation of traditional character encodings?

answers.text: wide usage in various countries of the world but remain largely incompatible with each other

qas.question: What characters does multilingual processors use?
What type of encodings do not allow bilingual computer processing?

plausible_answers.text: wide usage in various countries of the world but remain largely incompatible with each other

qas.question: What is the limitation of unicode globally?
What are traditional character encodings attempting to surpass?

context: <b9_0>Unicode<b9_0/> has the explicit aim of <a0_0>transcending the limitations of traditional character encodings<a0_0/>, such as those defined by the <b5_0>ISO 8859 standard<b5_0/>, which find <a4_0><b8_0>wide usage in various countries of the world but remain largely incompatible with each other<b8_0/><a4_0/>. Many <b7_0>traditional<b7_0/> character encodings share a common problem in that they allow bilingual computer processing (<a3_0>usually using <b6_0>Latin<b6_0/> characters<a3_0/> and the local script), but not <a1_0>multilingual computer processing<a1_0/> <a2_0>(computer processing of arbitrary scripts mixed with each other<a2_0/>).
